title: Ethereum Must Pass the Walkaway Test
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-13, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fthreadreaderapp.com%2Fthread%2F2010621884811845708.html%3Futm_source=tldrcrypto/1/0100019bb781c864-39446d0b-5bde-49c9-ad4a-0bedf0f90412-000000/TzbOn1efqVAIPnNQhKZLOCwzpPTGgoW9ohkrRXWgISk=440
summary: Ethereum Must Pass the Walkaway Test (2 minute read) Ethereum itself must be walkaway-safe (work without consistent EVM updates). This requires full quantum resistance, ZK-EVM and PeerDAS scalability, a decades-lasting state model, full account abstraction, a DoS-resistant gas schedule, a durable PoS economic model, and a block-building design that guarantees long-term censorship resistance.

title: How to write a good spec for AI agents
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 49 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Faddyosmani.com%2Fblog%2Fgood-spec%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019bbc3f1569-19465ac2-a0ee-4a24-95a6-c2f39e6dc77c-000000/_r_HGF1Z0dbQHyJWYKI_xeClLxpt1dO_hmNS6L545UA=440
summary: How to write a good spec for AI agents (49 minute read) Smart specs guide agents clearly, stay within practical context sizes, and evolve with projects. Aim to create clear specs that cover just enough nuance to guide the AI without overwhelming it. Break large tasks into smaller ones. Plan first in read-only mode before executing, and iterate continuously. This post presents a framework for spec-writing that keeps AI agents focused and productive.

summary: Why We Built Our Own Background Agent (15 minute read) Inspect is a custom background coding agent developed by Ramp that autonomously writes, verifies, and debugs code with the same context and tools a human engineer would use. The agent operates in fast, sandboxed VMs with full development environments, integrates with many existing tools, and supports interfaces like Slack, web, and Chrome extensions. Inspect was adopted quickly internally, writing approximately 30% of merged pull requests.

title: How a 40-Line Fix Eliminated a 400x Performance Gap
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 13 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fquestdb.com%2Fblog%2Fjvm-current-thread-user-time%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bbc69ad50-6dfc025c-e5b3-4edf-9df6-d42ae34eb166-000000/XqgISVjPZK5t0PCBlIPGLy1zcEbs_eeTsTkihEbCZfs=440
summary: How a 40-Line Fix Eliminated a 400x Performance Gap (13 minute read) A method in OpenJDK on Linux previously suffered from a severe 30x-400x performance gap. The slower implementation was due to standards requiring a less direct approach for user CPU time, unlike the faster `clock_gettime()` function used for total CPU time. A recent 40-line fix exploited an obscure yet stable Linux kernel detail to enable `clock_gettime()` to directly retrieve user-time-only, improving performance a lot.

title: React has finally solved its biggest problem: The joys of useEffectEvent
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.logrocket.com%2Freact-has-finally-solved-its-biggest-problem-useeffectevent%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bbc69ad50-6dfc025c-e5b3-4edf-9df6-d42ae34eb166-000000/LcrQGI8xcvAhGf3FRmvdX9S152JKbN5yeMIflaUDqE4=440
summary: React has finally solved its biggest problem: The joys of useEffectEvent (8 minute read) React has finally introduced the `useEffectEvent` Hook to solve its biggest problem: infinite loops and stale closures caused by `useEffect` dependency arrays. The hook provides a cleaner solution than the traditional `useRef` workaround by allowing devs to access current state values within effects without triggering re-runs when those values change.

title: No management needed: anti-patterns in early-stage engineering teams
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 9 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.ablg.io%2Fblog%2Fno-management-needed%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bbc69ad50-6dfc025c-e5b3-4edf-9df6-d42ae34eb166-000000/Dn4D0x6dExk4ZAMtQKIi9QLQdIIx3B2YlzexW62Q6Es=440
summary: No management needed: anti-patterns in early-stage engineering teams (9 minute read) For early-stage founders facing engineering management issues, the optimal solution is often to do nothing, focusing instead on building the product and engaging with users. Attempting to actively "motivate" engineers (who should be inherently motivated hires), hiring dedicated managers prematurely, and copying complex management practices from large companies like Google are the wrong things to do.

title: Every GitHub Object Has Two IDs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.greptile.com%2Fblog%2Fgithub-ids%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bbc69ad50-6dfc025c-e5b3-4edf-9df6-d42ae34eb166-000000/q0qlxtoqeZ30aPSbBEG4DAcmxp5TAjPqFTO1MdyEL94=440
summary: Every GitHub Object Has Two IDs (7 minute read) When building a feature for Greptile, this dev encountered an issue generating clickable GitHub links because their system stored GraphQL `node IDs` (e.g., `PRRC_kw...`), while web URLs required integer database IDs. Further investigation showed that GitHub uses two ID formats: an older, string-based system for legacy objects and a newer, more complex system for modern objects, despite inconsistent application.

summary: npm to Implement Staged Publishing After Turbulent Shift Off... title: Zumba's revenue growth from app2web flows
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgrowthgems.substack.com%2Fp%2Fgrowth-gems-138-user-research-retention%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019bbc739980-f722cf0a-bead-4855-bc4d-fa6ede2ad22e-000000/tG5AQefeTgbcPLyHyNsdEUWS9-1gNWCTX1ywEQ0ksCg=440
summary: Zumba's revenue growth from app2web flows (5 minute read) Zumba increased lifetime value by over 17% by shifting high-intent users from in-app purchases to app2web checkout, accepting lower initial conversion in exchange for higher retention, higher trial-to-paid rates, and elimination of app store fees. Conversion friction was reduced by mirroring native purchase flows, pre-selecting plans in-app, defaulting to Apple Pay or Google Pay, and auto-redirecting users back to the app post-purchase.

title: How simple semantics increased our AI citations by 642%
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fblog.hubspot.com%2Fmarketing%2Fhow-simple-semantics-increased-our-ai-citations-by-642-new-results%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019bbc739980-f722cf0a-bead-4855-bc4d-fa6ede2ad22e-000000/mG_pnNo4iKeyp1aEis6cGX6Ds69NjbabHbywDZsVbHc=440
summary: How simple semantics increased our AI citations by 642% (5 minute read) HubSpot increased page citations by AI tools by rewriting key content into semantic triples (sentences structured as subject-predicate-object). Pages were restructured so core concepts appeared early and in answer-first phrasing, helping AI models reliably associate HubSpot with categories like marketing automation. This change was implemented alongside existing SEO fundamentals such as schema and backlinks.

title: Is It Time to Kill All the Mascots?
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 2 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmusebyclios.com%2Fmusings%2Fis-it-time-to-kill-all-the-mascots%2F%3Futm_source=tldrmarketing/1/0100019bbc739980-f722cf0a-bead-4855-bc4d-fa6ede2ad22e-000000/o7tpgCB0FR0QPXcWO2tpnh62oSu3m9cla5jHTjpjzTY=440
summary: Is It Time to Kill All the Mascots? (2 minute read) Creative teams should challenge default mascot requests and evaluate whether other brand assets can better communicate value. Strategic alternatives such as distinctive color systems and direct language can stand out more effectively than anthropomorphic characters. Mascots should be a deliberate choice tied to long-term brand strategy, not a reflexive response to category trends or competitors.

title: The hidden cost of PostgreSQL arrays
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fboringsql.com%2Fposts%2Fgood-bad-arrays%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019bbc7b9b13-bbd5f8d3-5e71-4451-b5a4-96a458134216-000000/xDG-9QiPRQB7ka-AlcGc9tcm5oJ_KYHitnkRijLUBcE=440

title: Stopping Kill Signals Against Your eBPF Programs
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fsubstack.bomfather.dev%2Fp%2Fstopping-kill-signals-against-your%3Futm_source=tldrinfosec/1/0100019bbcd606f9-972ee35d-63cd-4202-8bef-5a9cd6b125ca-000000/AmuX8BWR1VU-hHMqBbSyNWq6bsW5SjyDAHyBn0I0cX4=440
summary: Stopping Kill Signals Against Your eBPF Programs (5 minute read) When malicious processes gain elevated privileges, they can disable eBPF agents, weakening a system's security posture. To prevent this, defenders can hook security_task_kill to prevent kill signals from reaching the eBPF agent. However, this also blocks any kill signals sent by defenders, such as to upgrade the agent. Defenders can instead set the eBPF hook to accept a signed signal with a nonce for restarts.

title: The Danger of Borrowed AI Certainty
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-14, Reading time: 5 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Frussmiles.substack.com%2Fp%2Fthe-danger-of-borrowed-ai-certainty%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019bbcdeb03d-56ee2c22-3a71-4bc9-9f34-18422a70ac1f-000000/gXM5LTHkuWvyhgLTZp_Ke70e8bbL_dNe-kyx3WnpAAM=440
summary: The Danger of Borrowed AI Certainty (5 minute read) AI introduces "borrowed certainty" in software, creating technical debt by replacing proof and evidence with confident-seeming predictions. Developers often mistake AI's fluency for validity, risking decisions based on unearned certainty. Best practices include treating AI output as a hypothesis, demanding traceability, ensuring human understanding, and pairing AI with execution feedback.

summary: How Uber Conquered Database Overload: The Journey from Static Rate-Limiting to Intelligent Load Management (12 minute read) Uber replaced static rate limiting with Cinnamon, an intelligent load management system embedded in its storage layer. It used concurrency-based detection, priority queues (t0‚Äìt5), pluggable regulators, and PID auto-tuning to dynamically shed load and adjust timeouts. This achieved 80% higher throughput, ~70% lower P99 latency, and ~93% fewer peak goroutines.

summary: Talk with your hands to be more persuasive (3 minute read) Using hand gestures while presenting increases perceived competence. It also increases persuasiveness and positive audience reactions by up to 9%. In an analysis of 2,184 TED talks and 200,000 clips, each doubling of hand movements led to 5.18% more YouTube likes. In experiments, a circular gesture during a face cream pitch drove 9% more positive responses than no motion and 7.7% more than pointing.

summary: The Traps of Borrowed Internal Developer Platform Roadmap Certainty (5 minute read) Internal developer platform roadmaps accumulate debt by treating borrowed industry trends as certainties. To avoid building useless features, teams must treat roadmap items as testable hypotheses.

title: JSON Render
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-15, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fvercel-labs%2Fjson-render%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bc18f3467-53bdd01b-3ddf-4d8f-b67c-212907ef7c4c-000000/Vriiyp6DfycbjM8wj2EPKlcfw3I-bmuFiVDrvbCCscY=440
summary: JSON Render (GitHub Repo) JSON Render is a library that gives AI the ability to safely generate UI, such as dashboards and widgets, from prompts. It requires devs to define a catalog of allowed components and actions, which constrains the AI's output to predictable, schema-validated JSON. This guardrailed approach makes sure the AI-generated UI is always predictable, secure, and can stream and render progressively.

title: Getting Real Leverage from Claude Code
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-15, Reading time: 18 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Festsauver.com%2Fblog%2Fclaude-code-workflow%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019bc18f3467-53bdd01b-3ddf-4d8f-b67c-212907ef7c4c-000000/TTximtc-BFetaLKHPNVqhKT700ZfXpqjm6voxHtHCZA=440
summary: Getting Real Leverage from Claude Code (18 minute read) Traditional Git worktrees alone when using Claude Code are not enough as they lead to shared resource conflicts like port contention and database clashes. Instead, it's better to use a local Kubernetes cluster (k3d) to provide true namespace isolation for each worktree, with Claude assisting in writing the necessary, often tedious, YAML configurations.

title: Understanding Manus sandbox - your cloud computer
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-01-15, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fmanus.im%2Fblog%2Fmanus-sandbox%3Futm_source=tldrai/1/0100019bc2241607-f5a37010-6509-48ec-8b5a-649ef5c46c99-000000/oTFfEMDNoeF34rIVqZucwYoFcsCTP55EHsgsoSB1KLw=440
summary: Understanding Manus sandbox - your cloud computer (7 minute read) Manus Sandbox is a fully isolated cloud virtual machine that runs in its own environment. Manus allocates a sandbox for each task and can execute sandboxes in parallel. Sandboxes have full capabilities, including networking, file systems, a browser, and various software tools. They can work around the clock to complete assigned tasks without consuming local resources.

MCP tools will otherwise work exactly as before.

summary: Is the 'Privacy-first' Era Over Before It Started?
